scenes.location: REMOTE AIRSTRIP AT THE RIVER'S EDGE
characters: DEAD ANIMALS ARE TO BE DOUBLE BAGGED AND
FLASHING. PAWS CLAWING AT US THROUGH THE BARS.
THE VAN RUNS RIGHT OFF THE BLUFF
ANYONE ENTERING ANIMAL ROOMS MUST HAVE
FACE TO FACE WITH TWO MEN --
VIRUS, EBOLA VIRUS, MANTAAN VIRUS, CRIMEAN-CONGO
WE PUSH IN TIGHT ON THE PLASMA BAG
THE MONKEY SLAMS INTO THE CAGES --
A STEAMING TURKEY FLOATING THROUGH THE AIR
JAMIE IS SHOVED THROUGH THE WALL INTO THE SLAMMER.
JOHNSON PULLS HER TO THE DECK --
THE FACE OF JAMIE RUNS TOWARDS US IN SLOW MOTION
IT RUNS RIGHT UP HER ARM AND RIGHT OVER HER HELMET --
KLAGES GETS RIGHT IN HIS FACE
THE FOOTBALL SPIRALS THROUGH THE AIR --
A PHOTO OF FIVE YOUNG MEN AND ONE YOUNG WOMEN
THE VIEW ROCKETS IN ON TINY
THE POLICE HELICOPTER ARRIVES HOVERING OVERHEAD
FOLLOW HOSKINS THROUGH THE SLAMMER TO
MONKEY EYES STARING AT US. NOSES BLEEDING. FANGS
THE VIEW ROCKETS UP UP INTO THE TREES --
A WATERFALL CRASHES ONTO ROCKS BELOW
THE STAGING ROOM DOOR SUDDENLY OPENS AGAIN --
FOLLOW PETER AND C.J. OUT THE DOOR
GAS FUMES ENGULF THE ROOM AND OBLITERATE THE VIEW
A MONKEY LIKE CREATURE HANGS DOWN RIGHT IN HER FACE --
PLEASE CONTACT ME AT EARLIEST CONVENIENCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rivers, teeming with microscopic life thread like spaghetti through a geography of living cells.  Invaders. Territory is overrun.  The view is like an aerial recon photo of an alien land -- at war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rivers, gleaming in the sun, thread like spaghetti throug a geography of jungle terrain, perfectly matching the patterns of the virus landscape.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: A Fokker light air transport descends into view.

dialogues.speaker: THE JUNGLE
dialogues.text: As the transport busses overhead, AFRICAN GREEN MONKEYS, hundreds of them, frolic and chatter in the trees. A BIG MALE watches inquisitive.  The plane's SHADOW passe over him.  The Male opens its mouth frighteningly wide; a "threat display."  Four HUGE FANGS flash at the intruder.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUING ACTION
dialogues.text: Twenty five feet above the Ebola River.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Transport touches down and stops on the empty field.

dialogues.speaker: THE TRANSPORT
dialogues.text: A Land Rover emerges.  Then another.  "WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION" emblems on the side panels.  We see a SIX PERSON MULTINATIONAL EPIDEMIC TEAM inside. Hermetically sealed hospital isolator stretchers with its own air supply sticks out the back of each.  A casualty inside can't infect the world outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the Rovers speeding into the bush.  Cargo doors close.  Engines rev.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Picking up speed.

dialogues.speaker: THE TREETOPS
dialogues.text: The plane BARELY CLEARS the trees sending Green Monkeys scattering in all directions.  Their angry cries echo;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A handful of ZAIREAN POLICE guard the primitive landing. REFUGEE VILLAGERS camp along the banks in the b.g. One POLICEMAN passes out half-cooked monkey. The POLICE CAPTAIN chews on a bloody haunch, licking his fingers.  The Ferry Bell RINGS O.S. Now a jeep HORN HONKS O.S. approaching --

dialogues.speaker: THE EBOLA RIVER
dialogues.text: The primitive Ferry parts the mist.  Four wooden canoes held together by a plank deck.  FERRYMEN buck the current with long poles. KARL JOHNSON EMERGES from the mist.  He stands on the hoo of the lead Rover WEARING A FULL FACE RESPIRATOR.  A creature from another planet.

dialogues.speaker: WITH THE FERRY
dialogues.text: CHUCK REESE (22) honks at the wheel.  He wears a full respirator.  All the team members wear respirators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not shoot.  Do not shoot. American Doctor!  Doctor!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: He raises his respirator staring right into the guns -- A 30, he's already a legendary field virologist. He surveys the scene like a military general as the Ferry lands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnson.  Center for Disease Control. U.S.A. -- We're headed to the Yambuku Mission. He points to his armband; CDC shield -- U.S. flag. Police respond yelling threats at the frightened Ferrymen and banging their weapons on the Rovers.

dialogues.speaker: REESE
dialogues.text: He is about to soil his trousers.  The two Norwegian Team members whisper in their language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, these people should be quarantined.  This outbreak is outta control --

dialogues.speaker: THE FRIGHTENED VILLAGERS
dialogues.text: Meager belongings, hungry children, terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far to Yambuku? Silence.  The Police Captain approaches menacingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to go there, Doctor. There is nothing but death there. People are dying all along the river -- SISTER GENEVIEVE, a Belgian Catholic Nurse, approaches from the Refugee camp.  40's, haggard, suffering dehydration.  She pushes past the Police, unafraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Etes-vous Doctor Johnson? (in English)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I am Sister Genevieve from the Yambuku Mission -- Johnson offers a bottle of Perrier -- Sister chugs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless you, Doctor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save the blessings, Sister -- He signals to Reese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reese, get the Sister some salt tablets and a shot of B12.  She's dehydrating. Petrified, Reese breaks out the medical kit from the Rover.  A Policeman tracks his every move at gunpoint. He is so nervous he fumbles the salt tablets and vitamins dropping them.  Sister politely pushes the guns aside and helps him pick them up. Johnson watches her.  He's impressed by her courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell our hosts I need blood samples -- Sister, tissue samples -- before this bug burns itself out.  I have to get to Yambuku.  If I can find one survivor, then We, not God, can maybe cure this thing. The Captain separates them.  He sticks his gun in Johnson's crotch.  He understands English perfectly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in English)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not be coming back this way, Doctor.  Quarantine -- (pointing to the jungle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will shoot you if you try. Johnson tosses packs of cigarettes to the Police defiantl and climbs back in the Rover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are certifiable, Dr. -- Suddenly, Sister Genevieve straightens her habit and jump in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall guide you to Yambuku, Doctor. Johnson starts to protest.  He sees her conviction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless You, Sister. THE VIEW CLIMBS as the Rover speeds off the landing and disappears into the bush.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON
dialogues.text: Sitting vigil crouched outside a hut.  Eyes fixed -- unwavering.  WE HEAR:  Horrible sounds of suffering inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huts burn and smolder.  Termite ant hills tower over some of the remains.  A handful of BANTU watch the old Elder. The Women wails a death chant. A HAND reaches out the doorway to bowls of food and water Suddenly, it clenches in agony.  Blood hemorrhages throug pulpy skin.  The hand flops to the dirt. The Elder rises in silence.  Torch in hand, he chants a prayer and torches the hut. A BANTU WOMAN screams rushing towards her flaming home. OTHER WOMEN pull her back. The Elder picks up his medicine bundle and leads the survivors of his Village into the Bush.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROVERS
dialogues.text: Johnson signals to go slower.  Reese is riveted to his window.  Burned devastation everywhere.  Sister prays.

dialogues.speaker: CHARRED BODIES
dialogues.text: Smoldering in the ruins.  Reese is sickened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, what happened here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bantu.  They've gone back to their ancient ways of dealing with plague and malaria.  You put the sick person in a hut.  You put food and water in the door.  If the person walks out one day -- or crawls out, that's fine.  If they don't... you burn the hut... No more disease --

dialogues.speaker: FOLLOW THE SECOND ROVER
dialogues.text: Two Team Members crank photographs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rovers stop nearby.  Sister Genevieve, exhausted, rests her head on the seat. Johnson climbs out surveying the sight.  This is his war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This whole zone is hot.  Reese. He kicks at the hut's burning embers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever this bug is, Ebola is not a place we're gonna forget anytime soon -- He turns to:  REESE, who is frantically removing his gear from the lead Rover.  He shoots Karl a frightened glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going upcountry, Doc.  I'm taking my team out -- We'll base at the hospital in Kinshasa -- Reese passes Johnson heading for the other Rover.  The Team reacts confused as he plops his gear inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good doctor.  They need your services too.  Couple of things you might consider -- Reese doesn't want to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we've already been exposed. As Karl speaks, he ties off his own arm, thumps a vein an draws his own blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Test all our blood when you get back.  Take some samples from Sister Genevieve:  here too --

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE ROVER
dialogues.text: Sweat beads on her forehead under her habit.  Her vision BLURS for a millisecond then corrects itself.  She watche Johnson confront Reese without ever raising his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe this bug can spread through the air.  Maybe it's the Andromeda Strain -- Johnson tosses the blood vial --

dialogues.speaker: TO REESE
dialogues.text: He stares at the blood vial like death itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it is Andromeda, then you won't be safe anywhere in the world. The Team audibly reacts in French and Norwegian.  Winds kick up smoke swirling around Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might as well be here at the epicenter trying to stop it.

dialogues.speaker: LOOKING DOWN
dialogues.text: The lone Rover travels slowly along the rough road.  In the f.g., GREEN MONKEYS FOLLOW, jumping from limb to branch, escorting Johnson deeper into the jungle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The infection hit the hospital like a -- like a bomb --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was the index case?  The first patient to "show"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Schoolteacher.  We treated him for malaria -- Two days later, he died -- horribly.  Every child at the school came to the hospital. Families -- pregnant women.  All broke with fever. Johnson traces the spread in his mind, sorting, seeking -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But where did the teacher get the bug?  Rodent bites? -- Feces? Mosquitoes?  Monkeys maybe? Sister Genevieve shakes her head bewildered.  Who knows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did it spread so quickly?  What did you give the patients?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Injections.  Chloroquine and vitamins.  These people do not believe they have been "doctored" unless we give them a shot... She hesitates, almost confessing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We only used five syringes a day to treat everyone --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grim diagnosis)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then the infection could've been passed through the needles --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God forgive us... Some became irrational -- hostile -- and escaped!  Hundreds became violently ill and died in one week -- Silence.  Johnson realizes he's facing nature's revenge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven days.  No time for an "immune response."  By the time the patient's immune system throws antibodies to fight the damn thing -- it's too late... She breaks down, sobbing.  Johnson stops the Rover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did what you could, Sister. He takes her hands in his, firmly but gently.  He's wearing surgical gloves.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD
dialogues.text: The Yambuku Mission.  An imposing old chapel and a ring o cinderblock buildings.  The Belgian flag hangs at half- mast in the center.  No life anywhere -- Suddenly, a FOUR FOOT TALL MALE GREEN MONKEY drops on the hood from the trees with full force -- screeching at them Sister screams with fright.  Johnson jumps so much he bumps his head on the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Swarm the Rover on a food search, screeching "KRA, KRA."

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: One Monkey lands on the door latch.  It's weight pulls th Sister's door open.  She cries out. JOHNSON FALLS across her closing it tight.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Flashes his fangs and hurls his feces, splattering agains the windshield.  Then he is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open air porches are lined with empty beds.  Silence. Only the chattering of the monkeys in the trees.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: He now wears a Tyvek protective suit, boots and full face respirator.  He carries a field kit and a small ice chest

dialogues.speaker: THE HOSPITAL
dialogues.text: Flies buzz swarming out the windows and doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnson opens the door.  Light spills in.  Flies swarm. Their buzzing sounds like chainsaws.

dialogues.speaker: THE WARD
dialogues.text: A silhouette of tangled bodies.  The mud walls are splattered with blood -- as if a bomb did go off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't come in here, Sister.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Sinks slowly to her knees, frozen like a statue, praying.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME
dialogues.text: Down the rows of 120 beds, inspecting the few remaining bodies, each with evidence of massive hemorrhaging from every orifice.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: He stops at one bed, carefully checking a YOUNG MAN for signs of life.  He feels for a pulse -- His glove fingers sink into the man's flesh like pudding. Johnson reels back -- reviled.  His breath labored.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON
dialogues.text: Taking a nose swab blood sample.  Another swab inside the Man's mouth -- and ears.  With tweezers, he pinches out samples of skin tissues. WE FOLLOW bloody swaps and skin tissues into plastic vials.  Johnson tags and places each in the ice chest.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE ICE CHEST
dialogues.text: Numbers:  001, etc., then, "Yambuku blood and epidermal tissue slices - Ebola, Zaire."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnson exits, exhausted, solemn.  Sister Genevieve is still bent in prayer, motionless; wearing her respirator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No survivors.  I've never seen a bug kill like this one, Sister. Fried by his experience, he surveys the jungle.  Surreal in the golden light.  He's completely spaced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be members of some lost tribe out there who've built up immunities to this killer over the years -- Their blood could have powerful antibodies passed down through the generations... strong enough to save some lives -- (silence, he reaches her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister --

dialogues.speaker: SISTER GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: Slowly raises her bowed head.  Blood oozes from her respirator.  Her faceplate is splattered with it. She collapses before he can catch her.  Johnson cradles her removing the respirator.  He's horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You spiked the damn fever -- We'll get you to Kinshasa. Blood traces from her tearducts -- her nose and ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god -- hold on -- hold on -- He pulls a syringe from his pocket -- thumps up a vein an begins to shoot her full of antibiotics.  She reflexes away from the needle -- internal hemorrhages rock her -- Johnson jerks back.  The SYRINGE PIERCES the glove on his left hand.  He stares at it in horror.  He yanks it out sucking his hand and spitting -- like a snake bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First... come... the... headaches -- She spasms suddenly -- coughing up black fluid --

dialogues.speaker: THE VIEW ROCKETS UP UP INTO THE TREES --
dialogues.text: Monkeys cry everywhere.  "KRA!  KRA!"  We rocket right into the face of the BIG GREEN MALE.  Deep brown cloudy eyes staring at us transfixed.  Blood -- building in a crimson wave -- emerges from it's nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modest colonial sits atop a hill at the foot of the Appalachians.  Leaves glow in bright autumn colors. SUPER:  FREDERICK, MD - WED., OCT. 4, 1989 0800 HRS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason -- you'll be late for school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE FREEZER DOOR CLOSES REVEALING:  COL. NANCY JAXX; a rather beautiful woman in her mid 30's.  "Supermom" and "ultrawife" in Army uniform with Colonel's bars taking he usual stab at breakfast; throwing 4 waffles in the microwave -- cracking two eggs in a skillet -- She opens cabinet, gets mugs, dumps in instant coffee -- suddenly -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushes it away, annoyed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason!  Come feed Gumby or he's going in your omelette! No response.  The Kinkajoo wraps its prehensile tail around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaxx piggybacks the Kinkajoo and a cup of coffee through the converted sunporch.  It's filled with ANIMALS.

dialogues.speaker: FOLLOW JAXX BY THE ANIMALS
dialogues.text: Two fish tanks, a fish pond, exotic Parrots, Bright Red Eclectus, Cockatoos -- and four Yellow naped Amazons.  On sings an opera aria.  One wolf whistles as Jaxx passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ritual)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks boys.  Eat your heart out girls -- She steps over an old bulldog in the doorway.  The dog, MAGGIE, flatulates in her sleep.  Jaxx fans the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- Maggie -- please -- A loose scarlet Parrot walking behind Jaxx pecks Maggie's stumpy tail instantly rousing the old dog to a barking frenzy.  The Aviary adds squawks and screeches.

dialogues.speaker: JASON'S BASEMENT BEDROOM
dialogues.text: She opens the door on her 13 year old son, JASON; his lanky frame all over the bed, sleeping with his Walkman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason?  Wakey wakey -- She tosses the Kinkajoo through the air and closes the door, blocking the view.  WE HEAR:  Jason yell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaxx heads for the converted garage passing a red Toyota pickup parked in the drive.  The magnetic sign on the doo panel reads:  "JAXX VETERINARY CLINIC."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jaxx enters, BLACKHAWK, their big black hunting Bouvie bounds over to greet her. 6'3" GERRY JAXX is dipping his "boarders" in a tickbath. His haircut still military sharp.  Now a civilian, his years in the army reflect in his physical fitness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready for your fix -- ? Nancy offers him a cup of coffee --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Nance.  The life of a country veterinarian is sheer bliss. He's lying.  His hands are elbow deep in doggie-bath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw -- You miss the Army that much? Why not Re-enlist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never.  Then I would have to call you, "Colonel" -- He embraces her caressing her buns.  She caresses his back.  Somebody clears their throat O.S.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE GLASS SLIDING DOOR
dialogues.text: Their daughter -- Twelve year old JAMIE -- bounces in her sweat clothes.  She wears braces and never stops.  Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through glass doors)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are children present.  I mean -- "Hello"?

dialogues.speaker: TO MOM AND DAD
dialogues.text: Breaking their clinch, "caught."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Princess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go eat your breakfast -- or we'll be late for school --

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: She makes a face; a complete rebel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a minute -- watch me! She poises by a tree, as if beginning a floor exercise. Suddenly, the Kinkajoo leaps from a low branch landing on Jamie's head.  She jumps with a shriek. MOM AND DAD react, laughing.  Nothing dangerous here.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: The Kinkajoo clings to her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Gumby.  Let's show'em. She sets the creature down beside her, preps and throws a standing back flip with an Olympic finish. The Kinkajoo does a flip too.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE CLINIC
dialogues.text: Gerry applauds.  Jaxx indicates "time for school."  JASON wanders in, zombied.  He holds up seared waffles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breakfast is burned... again. Jamie walks in on her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still eating with your hands, butthead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can she talk to me that way, Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's try not to kill each other before Thanksgiving, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After Thanksgiving, she's toast. (Jamie swats him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, I need money for lunch --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a meet Friday, Mom.  You're coming aren't cha -- ? Before Jaxx can answer, Jamie literally throws aerials ou of the clinic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please -- no acrobatics in the -- Jamie pays no attention.  Gerry looks at Jaxx dismayed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets her stubbornness from you, Mrs. Jaxx.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you mean independence. She's your daughter -- Jaxx exits by a starving Jason.  Blackhawk jumps up snatching the burned waffle from his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHILDREN play in a sandbox.  A LITTLE BOY spoons up some sand and eats it.  Yukk.  He spites it all over the GIRL next to him.  Two more KIDS drink juice from the same cup

dialogues.speaker: IN THE F.G.
dialogues.text: In red letters:  "PACIFIC PRIMATES - MANILA, PHILIPPINES. Green Monkeys peer out from partition openings at the children.  Sniffing.  A new scent in this new land.  Some monkeys flash their fangs.  Others chatter.

dialogues.speaker: THE KIDS
dialogues.text: Kids stare back at the monkeys with giggles and delight. The WOMEN SUPERVISOR pulls two FIGHTING CHILDREN apart. The GIRL bites the BOY on the hand -- drawing blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An alley separates the Day Care Center from a windowless building.  MONKEY HANDLERS unload crates from a truck. The logo on the cargo doors read:  SYNERGY RESEARCH LABS. The handlers carry the Monkey crates into the rear of the building.  TINY WHIPPERT, the strawboss, wears overalls, plaid hunting shirt, ball cap, pony tail, a deer skinning knife and weighs about 350. DEKE, a biker type and LOC, a Vietnamese who speaks no English, help Tiny transfer the monkey crates from the truck one at a time.  They wear no masks -- just gloves. All are expert monkey handlers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love the part when Bruce Willis grins like he just got a little you know.  He hits that detonator and yells "adios mother fuckaouch!" He dumps his end of the crate wringing his hand in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow -- little cocksucker bit the shit -- outta me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're probably the little shit's first meal since it left Africa. Tiny shucks his glove and sucks his bloody finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got two hundred more to go, Tiny. You need more fingers. Tiny shoots him the "bloody" finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOMES.  The Monkey house is right in the middle of suburbia.  Twenty-five miles from Washington D.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The base spreads at the eastern slope of the Appalachian Mountains.  WE PASS OVER by an array of 90 foot radio dishes.  This is a major defense communications center. SUPER:  FT. DETRICK, MD - NOV. 16, 0900 HRS.

dialogues.speaker: WE DESCEND TO
dialogues.text: Vent stacks on the roof aim up at us like deck guns.

dialogues.speaker: THE BUILDING
dialogues.text: U.S.A.M.R.I.I.D.

dialogues.speaker: INSTITUTE OF INFECTIOUS DISEASES
dialogues.text: Insiders call it "RIID" for short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON USAMRIID SHIELD:  Twin serpents entwine around a flaming sword.  The slogan; "Research for the Soldier."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaxx enters waving to the camera. WIDEN TO:  A SECURITY GUARD sits vigil over a bank of monitors with exterior views of the entire facility; containment labs, corridors, monkey cages...

dialogues.speaker: ON ONE MONITOR
dialogues.text: A figure in a shiny space suit peers into a microscope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow Jaxx through the institutional halls.  At close double doors, she uses her security card on a necklace from inside her uniform blouse and swipes it across a black magnetic sensor on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME
dialogues.text: Doors spring open.  Jaxx enters.  A sign overhead reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaxx passes by individual containment rooms with several species of Monkeys in cages.  The place is spotless.  Eas listening ROCK MUSIC plays over the PA.

dialogues.speaker: AT A WINDOW PARTITION
dialogues.text: Jaxx stops to watch two young WOMEN; PFC, GODWIN (17) and SGT. KLAGES (18) wearing masks, Plexiglas visors and gloves as they vaccinate a big African Green Monkey.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE LAV ROOM
dialogues.text: Jaxx enters wearing a visor mask, visor and gloves. Godwin is singing softly to the monkey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, Jaxx --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting them at ease)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Ladies -- How's "Super Monk."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Super Monk is immune to Simian Hemorrhagic and he just threw off another heavy Lassa fever challenge. Strong antibody response.  He's the healthiest primate in captivity. Super Monk scarfs down monkey biscuits, ravenous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MOUSE CAGE; made of popsicle sticks.  Inside are three white mice made of pipecleaners.  Each wears a tinfoil ga mask.  A fading card on the side in a child's hand reads:

dialogues.speaker: "BE NICE TO MICE, K MOMMY
dialogues.text: A family photo sits on the cluttered desk next to it. Jaxx poses with Jamie holding a Gymnastics trophy. The phone RINGS... Again... Again.  JAXX HURRIES by the glass partition, enters and answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaxx --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fifty-year old Man on the phone looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stan Girard -- remember?  Synergy, right.  I'm chief research Vet. We've got a little problem at one of our quarantine units not too far from you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone, taking notes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five hundred Greens and Macaques -- shipped from Philippines six weeks ago -- Simian Hemorrhagic fever?

dialogues.speaker: TO GIRARD
dialogues.text: He examines a dissected monkey on a "bleed table" with gloves, his mask down around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Necropsies on the fatalities show enlarged spleens -- some petechiae --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Classic symptoms for SHF.  What's the body count? (a pause, eerie feeling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventy in the last week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Narrow.  Windowless.  Lined with 100 wall mounted stainless steel cages.  Live monkeys stare listless. Ghost-like.

dialogues.speaker: ON A CAGE
dialogues.text: A Monkey tumbles into his net.  Dead. TO TINY:  hosing down the blood on the floor kicking up a aerosol mist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We lost twenty-seven more this morning.  So far just one room is infected -- FOLLOW THE MIST:  Swirling up past monkey cages to ventilators in the ceiling --

dialogues.speaker: TO THE TREATMENT ROOM
dialogues.text: The fine mist rolls from a ceiling vent DOWN TO:  GIRARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, well, Management doesn't want to lose the whole population -- We've got over a quarter million dollars in these monkeys --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd keep that room isolated.  We know SHF isn't lethal to people, just monkeys -- Make sure your handlers use normal contagion precautions.  Yeah, get some "B&T" samples up to us today we'll get on it.  Right -- She hangs up tentatively, then hurries out.  PUSH IN ON: The pipecleaner mice wearing gas masks.

dialogues.speaker: MICROSCOPIC VIEW
dialogues.text: A carpet of living cells takes on a spider web look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liver cells.  Monkey sample #053 -- What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaxx adjusts the view wearing gloves and surgical masks for Biosafety Level 3 lab. PETER JAHRLING turns the glass flask containing the cell culture under the microscope.  Late 30's, garrulous, blac heavy glasses; the quintessential lab scientist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like Simian to me.  The infected cells have a definite spider web look. He studies the magnified image on a video monitor attache to the microscope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's another bug in this house anyway -- ? He points through a glass partition to two industrial sized refrigerators, both with computer locks.  The RED TREFOIL symbol for "biological hazard" marks the doors like skull and crossbones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got enough BL4 viruses and bacteria in there to make AIDS look like a runny nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, there's a happy thought.  I try not to think about it. (checking scope again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's be sure about this bug.  Run some antigens --

dialogues.speaker: THE LAB BENCH
dialogues.text: Jaxx removes one labeled "ANTIBODY SERUM - SIMIAN HF." She draws a drop of the liquid in a pipette -- then inserts it into the flask. Peter flicks on the ultraviolet scope light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go for the gold.

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO MICROSCOPE VIEW
dialogues.text: Cells glow in the ultraviolet.  Suddenly, the dark antige solution clouds the view.  Antibodies surround infected cells glowing bright fluorescent golden orange. Jaxx studies the scope as Peter refers to a chart.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHART
dialogues.text: He scans down bar graphs of fluorescent colors to a GOLDE ORANGE BAR labeled:  "Simian Hemorrhagic Fever."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingo.  Positive for SHF.  Good news for us -- bad news for the monkeys. Jaxx peers into the microscope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- there's something flaky going on in this flask --

dialogues.speaker: MICROSCOPE VIEW
dialogues.text: Blackholes grow in the carpet of glowing cells as if eate by moths.  Dead and dying cells float away --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not like any SHF I've ever seen.  Something is blowing those cells away.  They're off the plastic. She doesn't like it.  She pulls Peter to the scope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, just some crud in the scope. Pseudomonas bacterium maybe.  Really annoying.  Wipes out everything. You have to start over.  The little suckers smell like Welches grape juice -- He takes the flask, opens it and sniffs it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah and a virus kills with no odor -- So what've you got? Peter continues to sniff.  A look of consternation.  He suddenly caps it, getting the creeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing... No... smell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay -- so we've got an "unknown" here, Pete -- Jaxx flares concern.  They both stare at the flask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's do it by the numbers.  How long will it take you to culture another isolate and get it on the big scope so we can see what the damn thing is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starts to sweat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll need more monkey samples.  Ten, twelve hours maybe.  First thing in the A.M.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heading for door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call your wife.  Tell her we're shacking up together.  I'm going to pump C.J. to get us some of those monkeys --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know -- Karl Johnson could tell just by looking if this crud was Lassa, Marburg, Ebola, Anthrax -- Peter sets the flask down gingerly.  Jaxx lingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a green recruit my first year here at RIID when Johnson "retired." I don't think he ever even knew who I was.  How come you mention his name around here, everyone crawls in a hole?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (matter of fact)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karl thinks the world's got a gun to its head and there's not a damn thing anyone can do to keep us from pulling the trigger. (a beat of respect)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That scares people in high places... He's the best bug man there is.  Why don't you ask him? Jaxx flusters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, okay -- but he's not here -- We are. Jaxx exits slamming the door.  The warning sign reads:

dialogues.speaker: TO PETE
dialogues.text: He ponders the flask for a moment.  He pulls on his surgical mask, pours the milky fluid from it into a test tube, places the tube in a centrifuge and turns it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whirls to a blur.

dialogues.speaker: A PHOTO OF KARL JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Staring right at us outside the Yambuku Mission.  1976. His Field Team and 2 Nuns flank him.  One of them is Sister Genevieve, alive.  With Village Children.  Smiles of hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaxx is transfixed on the photograph.  Thick files fill her desk.  She flips through more photos -- there it is.

dialogues.speaker: A PHOTO OF FIVE YOUNG MEN AND ONE YOUNG WOMEN
dialogues.text: Stand in front of a Huey Helicopter all wearing inflated orange spacesuits with clear bubble helmets.  They flank Karl Johnson beside a biomedical isolator litter.  The caption reads:

dialogues.speaker: EVACUATION TEAM
dialogues.text: PUSH IN ON:  the young woman -- PFC Nancy Jaxx, age 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She calls up a data base. ENTRY:  SEARCH FOR> JOHNSON, KARL M.

dialogues.speaker: FAX
dialogues.text: Jaxx hesitates.  She types a message quickly into the computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter works in the b.g.  WE MOVE IN ON THE TEST TUBE TO A MICROSCOPIC VIEW:  The geography of cells are at war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SHINY GYMNASTICS MEDAL is displayed in a place setting on the counter. JAXX ENTERS lugging files.  Blackhawk is there to greet her with licks and whines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, big guy.  You hungry?  So am I. She melts seeing the medal.  There's a note.  She reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your amazing daughter took second. Your amazing son washed the dishes. And your amazing husband put your dinner in the microwave.  Check the machine -- Nancy chuckles.  While the machine rewinds, she opens a cabinet and pulls down a can of dog food.  The electric can opener doesn't work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nance, Girard just called.  Seven more monkeys kicked.  They've got them on ice.  Meet C.J. there at 0800.  This guy Girard sounds spooked. She rifles the drawer.  No opener.  She uses a beer opene punching around the edge.  The lid bends in -- Her hand slips into the can -- slicing on the jagged edge She holds her fist in pain checking the damage.  Nothing. Then blood leeches from the clean cut on her right hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaxx twines a wide Band-aid over her wound and closes the medicine cabinet.  She jumps with fright at THE FACE leering right behind her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamie -- oh -- hon -- Jamie is half asleep -- still in her gym suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drowsy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't get first, Mom --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother and daughter enter arms around each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're proud of you even if you don't win.  I'm just sorry I had to miss your big moment -- Jamie falls into bed.  Jaxx pulls off her warmups by the pant legs.  Then the jacket.  She drifts off.  Jaxx kisse Jamie goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA ROCKETS along the cages right up to the last monkey.  Death stare.  A single stream of blood trickles from it's nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids head for school in packs.  CRANE DOWN TO:

dialogues.speaker: JAXX'S CAR
dialogues.text: Jason and Jamie exit heading for school.  Jaxx takes her daughter's hand.  Jamie squeezes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ritual)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "be nice to mice," Mom.  Promise. Remember, "all animals --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "All animals are our brothers and sisters." (polite parental tolerance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know -- I know, Princess.  Do good, you two -- Love you! Jaxx watches them head for school.  It's a Mom's life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids romp in the play-yard at the day care center. SUPER:  RESTON, VA. - WEDNESDAY, NOV. 17 - 0830 HRS. Jaxx's car is parked behind the station down the alley. She watches the kids from the payphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any results yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dragging from no sleep.  He spins another test tube in the centrifuge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got zip and I'm about out of monkey parts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're working on it.

dialogues.speaker: THE DAY CARE CENTER
dialogues.text: Kids eat mud-pies.  PAN TO:  The funky rear door to the monkey house.  Empty monkey crates are stacked in back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any messages?  I was expecting a fax --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nada.  Guess nobody loves you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Pete.  I needed that.

dialogues.speaker: COL. C.J. PETERS
dialogues.text: Heading up the alley her way.  He's pissed.  Forty. Thinning hair.  Bulging middle in his Army uniform. Deputy Commander of "RIID."  Brilliant virologist with a grim sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your happy face, C.J.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sardonic grin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girard's not going to let us in. He's afraid our army uniforms will "upset his staff."  Mercy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like this, C.J.  Day-care center -- little kids --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just worry about the monkeys. Girard said Management's already on him about calling in the Army.  Tell you one thing, whatever's going on in there, he's scared.  They're bringing the samples here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, free home delivery.  Nice.

dialogues.speaker: A LIME GREEN VAN
dialogues.text: Heads up the alley and stops beside them.  TINY WHIPPERT leans from the cab.  Big toothy grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.  How you, M'am?  Uh, General M'am -- ? Jaxx smiles putting the nervous Tiny at ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Col. Jaxx and this is Col. Peters Deputy Commander at RIID. Tiny shyly lumbers out revealing Deer Rifles in a rack behind his seat.  He ambles to the back, nursing coffee talking a bluestreak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got dead "cynos" ever day.  Y'all think y'all can find out what's killin'em, huh?

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE VAN
dialogues.text: Tiny opens the door.  Jaxx and C.J. gawk at 7 plastic garbage bags.  No one wants to be the first to grab one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Samples?" You brought whole monkeys?  Are they disinfected and triple bagged?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet.  Wouldn't want to get any on ya -- Jaxx is appalled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These Cynos all came from Room F?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.  Room H. Jaxx and C.J. trade concerned glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's jumped to a new room.  Do all the monkeys breathe the same air?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess so.  If a monkey even farts in one room, you can smell it in another.  No offense M'am -- Jaxx pulls C.J. behind her car.  Both unnerved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got a possible aerosol contaminant here -- and we know it's not Simian Fever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But -- it's lethal.  I'm a Veterinarian.  I can't knowingly transport a dead animal with an infectious disease across state lines without a permit.  I can lose my license.  No way it's going to stay quiet we transported them. You're a Doc.  You can plead ignorance. She thumps his big gold lapel bars --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This -- is why you get to wear those big eagles, Colonel, Sir --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And -- your car's shittier than mine. Jaxx bats her green eyes over the top "Miss Scarlett." C.J. starts to protest.  What's the use.

dialogues.speaker: C.J.'S TRUNK
dialogues.text: The monkey's weight depresses the rear end of his car. C.J. slams the lid.  It won't shut.  He and Tiny sit on it.  It closes with a sickening crunch.

dialogues.speaker: THE VAN
dialogues.text: Sweating profusely.  He squeezes a pain between his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: C.J.'S CAR
dialogues.text: Tiny waves.  Suddenly, Jaxx and C.J. BLUR in Tiny's vision.  He rubs his eyes.  His vision clears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need anymore, just holler.  Have a good one now, ya hear? C.J. waves morbidly as the VAN WIPES FRAME TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better follow you.  Make sure you don't... drip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.J. bottoms out on a bump exiting the drive.  Sparks fly

dialogues.speaker: TO JAXX
dialogues.text: She whiteknuckles her steering wheel waiting for his trun to pop open.  It holds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they pass by, a LITTLE BOY STANDS on top of the slide pounding his chest like King Kong -- making monkey faces. Kids run around scared and screeching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaxx hurries in and checks her message box.  She rifles them quickly.  No Johnson.  Damn --

dialogues.speaker: THE HOT SUITE ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: Jaxx swipes her security card over the sensor.  Pneumatic gaskets HISS retreating around the submarine style airloc door.  Jaxx hurries in.  The door seals shut behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaxx enters the staging area pulling on her scrubs and surgical cap.  The RED LIGHT glows over the BL4 airlock door.  She dials a wall phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete -- I'm going hotside.  Any last requests --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's running on fumes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, a monkey TV dinner.  We're striking out here.  Big zero. He mounts a button of cells on a slicer.  A diamond knife peels off a tiny slice.  He captures it on a tiny mesh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens a cabinet door.  Ultraviolet floods.  She pulls out a Blue spacesuit.  One piece, soft helmet, thick rubber gloves and foot molds -- like feet pajamas. She slides her right hand into a surgical glove.  The Band-aid over her cut hand is intact.  She then tapes the glove to her sleeve with brown sticky tape. Next she slides her gloved hands down the spacesuit sleeves into the heavier surgical gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A metal tower eight feet tall.  Peter places the cell slice in the chamber of the big scope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closing her diagonal zipper, then the airtight Ziploc. She heads into a stainless-steel multiheaded "envirochem" shower.  WE HEAR:  BREATHING.  Now her HEART BEAT, steady rhythmic.  Her faceplate fogs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE VIEWING SCREEN:  a cellscape appears.  Oxbow river and lakes like an aerial view of a jungle.  We've seen this view before.  An ominous sight --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coiled airhoses hang from the ceiling like spaghetti. Jaxx grabs one -- and hooks it into the short hose protruding from a "MEPA" filter canister on her thigh.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE JAXX'S SUIT
dialogues.text: A rush of air ROARS like a freight train.  Her faceplate clears.  She moves to a "pass through chute," opens it -- She pulls a monkey bag through onto a stainless steel bleed table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He scans the cellscape, like flying.  Searching.  He abruptly stops.  He stares in horror at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: THE VIEWING SCREEN
dialogues.text: So thick with virus it looks like buckets of rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit... oh... shit... Peter holds up a cellscape micrograph next to the viewing screen.  The picture is labeled:  EBOLA, ZAIRE; LUNG SLIC PATIENT 17, 1976.  It's loaded with the same virus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her gloved hand picks up a scalpel from the "sharps" box. She makes the chest incision O.S.  She raises her gloves back into view -- both are dripping with blood. She dunks both in the Clorox pan, cleaning them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter enters the suite from the shower in his spacesuit. He's distraught, carrying micrographs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaxx -- We got a problem -- No response.  He forgot his headset!  Sweat runs down his nose.  His faceplate fogs up.  He clamps on an airhose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They keep snapping apart.  Peter hurries down the corrido with no air, his breathing labored.

dialogues.speaker: JAXX IN LAB ROOM
dialogues.text: Probing the monkey.  Her gloves covered in blood.  Peter waves.  She doesn't see him.  He starts to pound the glass.  A warning sign stops him.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE JAXX'S SPACESUIT
dialogues.text: Air ROARS like a freight train.  She talks to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Subcutaneous hemorrhaging. Patiechial lung hemorrhages.  Rapid tissue deterioration -- This thing's a bag of soup -- Suddenly her air stops flowing.  What?  She turns to chec the hose.  SHE FACES PETER:  her hose squeezed tightly in his gloves.  He lets go.  Air flows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- what's up? He shoves the micrographs of Ebola up to her face plate. She takes them in her bloody gloves --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got crud in your scope. Peter indicates "no."  He's white as a ghost.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE SUITS
dialogues.text: His air hose hangs loose.  Jaxx quickly clamps him onto a spare hose.  She gets in his face.  He's panicked --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Ebola!  I sniffed that flask!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete!  There's a good chance you're not infected!  Don't go dinki-dao on me now.  Antibodies.  Let's test them.  Get some "Sister G" serum -- She points to the big refrigerator with all the viruses. He nods, composing himself.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE BIG FRIDGE
dialogues.text: A monolith in the dim light.  Pete punches in the compute combination.  The titanium lock chungs.  THE DOOR OPENS. Nitrogen fog spills out. FOLLOW PETE'S GLOVE:  searching vials and containers marked:  LASSA, MARBURG, ANTHRAX, HANTA, RIFT VALLEY, ENCEPHALITIS, AIDS, EBOLA -- to one marked:  "ANTIBODY

dialogues.speaker: TO JAXX AND PETE
dialogues.text: Peter places the slide under the fluorescent microscope with forceps.  Jaxx presses her face plate to the scope -

dialogues.speaker: MICROSCOPIC VIEW
dialogues.text: Crawling with the Filovirus.  Antibodies seize on the cells lighting the cellscape in a foreboding purple glow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These monkeys are loaded.  We've got to tell C.J. -- Peter freezes pointing at Jaxx's glove.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE SPACESUIT
dialogues.text: Jaxx holds her right glove up.  There's a huge hole between her thumb and forefinger.  She instantly reacts - JAMMING HER GLOVE in the Clorox washing it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaker -- oh shit --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Envirochem pounds her suit.  The system sign glows:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (humoring herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't die.  I don't have a baby- sitter.  Who'll feed my animals? Damn, I forgot to order the turkey for Thanksgiving.  I love Gerry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaxx draws her right arm from the spacesuit glove.  Her inner surgical glove is covered in monkey blood too. Panic.  She pours more Clorox over the glove scrubbing it viciously with a brush trying to wash away the threat.

dialogues.speaker: HER HAND
dialogues.text: As she peels the glove slowly off.  She reaches the Band-aid -- no monkey blood.  Her hand is clean. Jaxx fills the glove up like a balloon at the faucet. Final verdict.  No leaks. Peter plops relieved; his suit dripping from the shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No leaks.  I'm fine.  No problem -- She heaves -- throwing up in the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ebola Cellscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.J. sifts through the photos on the move.  Peter wears a surgical mask due to potential exposure.  Jaxx is wired -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the Lochness Monster, C.J.  All seven primates were loaded.  That monkey house is a viral time bomb --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His door says it all:  COMMANDER ARMY MEDICAL RESEARCH. C.J., Jaxx and Peter barrel by the startled RECEPTIONIST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Col. Peters, the General asked if this could wait until --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter.  GENERAL RUSSELL is getting ready to leave. C.J. shoves Pete's Ebola micrograph in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. He looks back at Jaxx, Pete and C.J.  It's not.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: A map of the world fills the view.  Colored pins mark locations of viral outbreaks.  JAXX ENTERS FRAME --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got a killer virus 25 miles from Washington D.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And five miles from the CIA.  Maybe this is no accident.  Maybe this is a new war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrorism?  Bio-warfare?  Here? Jaxx points to the "hot spots" in Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only Ebola outbreak on record -- the '76 outbreak in Africa.  Now -- you can put a pin right here.  How? She points to the black pins in Africa and travels with her forefinger across the Atlantic.  She dramatically sticks a new BLACK PIN right next to Washington D.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter how the bug got here -- it's here.  If word gets out, we've got a major panic on our hands.  If the virus breaks out -- we've got an epidemic.  A disaster. Russell looks at the Cellscapes again in grim silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete, are we anywhere close to a vaccine for this bug? Peter meekly lowers his surgical mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm close on synthetic antibodies. But no proof it'll work on humans. The only antibody serum we've got is from Johnson's Nun.  And there's only enough of that to try and save one patient -- maybe. He replaces his mask.  Everyone speaks at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody just slow down.  Millions of lives could be at stake.  It'd be nice if we had our shit together. Jaxx, C.J. and Peter grumble, duly admonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.J., I'm putting you and Jaxx in charge of this operation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to inform the CDC.  They're going to buck us for jurisdiction. This has to stay an Army operation. We need to get inside that monkey house as soon as possible before the bug gets outside --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, there's a day care center right behind the primate house that should be closed immediately --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate your concern, Colonel, but if you do that, word'll get out and we'll have to close down the whole town.  I am not prepared to give that order. Jaxx bristles.  "Hurry up and wait" as usual.  She holds up the electron micrograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'd like to fax these to Karl Johnson.  I want him in on the Epi- team controlling this thing. Instant shocked reactions from the men.  Peter pumps a fist -- "Yes" -- in support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karl?  That's a sure way to start a major-league panic.  He'll yell "fire" and scare the hell out of everybody.  Forget it.  He's retired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CDC and Karl Johnson in the same room is not a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's big trouble, Jaxx.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all due respect, Sir, we're already in trouble.  Johnson discovered Ebola and just about every other virus we're fighting. We need him. Peter agrees.  He drills C.J. in angry disbelief.  C.J. backs off -- getting angry with himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (self recrimination)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karl taught me everything I know.  I should've called him myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mischievous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already did.  Faxed him yesterday. Peter chuckles, digging at C.J.  Russell goes beet red. Jaxx prepares for the worst --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damnit, Jaxx -- He fumes -- then slowly caves in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, what the hell -- If you can find him -- bring him in.  I'll call the CDC and tell Reese.  They'll sure piss in their pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you -- Sir, Gentlemen -- guys. Jaxx is so pumped she's out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.J. -- call Girard.  Limit any contact his personal has with the monkeys.  Then get a hold of Virginia State Health, Interior, Agriculture -- find Col. Takafuji at the Surgeon General's office.  We'll have a "laydown" meet here as soon as possible so get your data in order. Russell grabs a phone -- man with a mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no doubt in my mind we've got a national emergency.  I don't want a panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Panic?" Yeah, right.  He didn't sniff that flask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reese?  Phil.  Hey, we got a problem up here.  Found a little pissant filo virus in a bunch of monkeys down the road.  Ebola.  What d'ya think about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you've got crud in your scope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaxx feeds the cellscape one by one into the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Johnson.  Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON ANOTHER FAX MACHINE
dialogues.text: Jaxx's faxes scroll from the machine curling to an old plank floor.  Then another.  And another.  HANDS PICK up the streams of faxes and place them in a cardboard box. "JOHNSON" is scrawled on it in crayon.  WE CRANE UP THE SIDE OF THE BOX:  running over with uncollected faxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnson's fax box sits on the floor next to a sleeping Sheepdog.  An eclectic general store.  Everything from bait to NY bagels and gourmet wines -- Faxes keep coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A neon "FAX" sign hangs in the dirty window.  WIDEN TO: bigger sign the reads:  "Auto Repairs - Video Rentals - Gourmet Wines - Stock Feed - Outfitters - UPS - Fedex - Xerox Copies." SUPER: THURSDAY, NOV. 18 - BIG SKY, MONTANA - 0900 HRS.

dialogues.speaker: JAXX
dialogues.text: Taking in the eclectic sight.  She gets out and heads in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaxx exits toting the faxbox, a bundle of mail, some fishing tackle and two-fifths of Dewars Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As far as we can see.  Snow capped peaks.  PAN DOWN TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KARL JOHNSON - HIS BACK TO US:  stands waist-deep in the middle of the river.  Still in his favorite fishing hat, he rips his line off the water and lays a cast upstream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Johnson?!

dialogues.speaker: JAXX
dialogues.text: Tentative.  She yells again over the roaring rapids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karl Johnson?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to us, surprised.  He's twelve years older.  His features elegantly weathered over the decades.  He studie Jaxx with those piercing eyes -- like a Bear sizing her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Nancy Jaxx.  Remember? -- I was a PFC in the Medical Corps your last year at "RIID." He clearly doesn't recognize her.  He gets a strike upstream.  Bad timing for Jaxx.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You trained me with the first Airborne medical isolator team. He shrugs annoyed walking upstream reeling in his fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a women in the A.I.T. unit?  And I don't remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ego bruised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was the only woman in that unit. Now I'm in Special Pathogens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (testy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  So was I.  Now, I'm retired. Can't you see I'm fishing?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.J. Peters sent me!  I have to talk to you about Ebola! Johnson reacts even more annoyed.  He nets his fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't do any lectures until the spring.  Contact me then -- He looks his prize brown trout in the eye and lets it go.

dialogues.speaker: THE RIVER
dialogues.text: Jaxx watches the fish swim away -- Then she watches the man who set it free.  There is a nobility about him as he makes his way upstream to his Drifter Boat resting on the shore.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE DRIFTER BOAT
dialogues.text: Johnson stows his gear and starts to shove off.  Jaxx climbs in.  Johnson thinks she's nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look -- I flew all night in a military transport to get here.  And I heard your "Emerging Viruses" talk at the Trop-med conference two years ago -- in case you don't remember. It was -- fascinating.  See how this makes you feel? She pulls a folder from her daypack and shoves it to him. Johnson eyes her warily as he opens it.  He stares at --

dialogues.speaker: PETER'S EBOLA MICROGRAPHS
dialogues.text: Old ghosts haunt him.  PUSH IN ON JOHNSON'S EYES:  Fixed on the image.  SOUNDS OF AFRICA surround him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless you include the feeling generated by gazing into the eyes of a cobra, "fascination" is not what I feel about Ebola. (looks right at Jaxx)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about 'Shit scared'? Johnson abruptly casts off.  Jaxx almost falls in.

dialogues.speaker: FOLLOW THE BOAT
dialogues.text: Through the rapids.  Jaxx whoops hanging on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's never been a case of Ebola isolated on this continent!  How in the hell did it get to Virginia?! He guides the Drifter expertly up a swell and crashes dow into a chute.  Jaxx yells again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I came to find you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnson and Jaxx pull the Drifter ashore in the calm of a backwater.  His Cabin is visible set back in the trees.

dialogues.speaker: JAXX AND JOHNSON
dialogues.text: He's pumped annoyed and angry all in the same moment.  Th world has intruded on him here in paradise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about exposure?  Anybody died yet?  Anybody spiked fever?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the monkeys.  And one exposure at our lab so far. He stops Jaxx in her tracks -- getting right in her face --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know that for sure -- do you?  Do you?  You don't know how many people this bug could be incubating in do you?  And I'll bet my hat the CDC doesn't know either. She doesn't.  He doesn't wait for an answer.  He stalks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I warned them this would happen. They didn't see what I saw in Africa.  As long as these viruses are killing black people and yellow people and red and brown in far off places -- why should we give a big woolly damn here at home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bumps the door open and enters.  Jaxx hesitates, bristling, pumping herself up, she follows him inside. It's an eclectic collection of fishing gear, Indian art, African and South American artifacts, carvings, photos --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Johnson, I think you should know the Ebola vaccine has been a priority at RIID --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you haven't got one yet, do you? Do you? Jaxx shakes her head "no" guiltily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know where Ebola comes from? Huh?  The natural host?  The reservoir?  After all these years? -- Take a wild guess -- Jaxx angrily shakes "no."  He opens the Dewars --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say monkeys.  The Virus kills them too quick for a monk to be a host.  Twelve years and we still don't know what animal, vegetable, mineral or insect Ebola comes from. -- fishing a glass from a shelf, he fills it and knocks i back.  No sympathy from Jaxx.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you hiding out here for? He shoots her a lethal look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, "fishing."  I mean -- why did you retire?  Quit your research? He pours another and one for her.  His voice calms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  Because nobody really wants to cure these diseases.  The Bureaucrats and Doctors would rather fight over who gets credit -- and who patents the cure. (hands her a drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world's got a gun to it's head and there's nothing I can do to keep it from pulling the trigger. It absolutely predestined truth the way Karl says it. Jaxx heard Peter say it.  She heard enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- You don't remember me, but I remember this about you -- I heard you say the best place to be in an outbreak is at the epicenter... trying anything possible to stop it -- I guess I was mis-informed... She returns the full glass, completely disillusioned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go... fishing. She shakes perfunctorily and heads for the door.  Johnson watches her go with profound regret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- Jaxx.  We found another virus in a lot of the blood samples we took in Zaire.  AIDS. Jaxx stops.  Chilled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had AIDS samples back in '76?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  But it wasn't killing anyone. Ebola was. He chokes it off.  Pain and sorrow in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could've been ready for AIDS.  We could've saved some lives. Jaxx stares at him in stunned silence, reeled by the ramifications.  She has a better understanding of this man's pain -- and a deeper respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone knows "it's not nice to fool with Motha Nate-cha." Now she's got us by the -- He gestures squeezing with a cupped hand -- He cuts himself off, suddenly an embarrassed gentleman --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Balls," Karl.  She's got us by the balls. Their eyes meet.  She's pried him loose.  He's ready.  He offers her the full scotch glass.  She clinks it against his.  They knock the Scotches back.  Warriors going to war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA GLIDES THROUGH:  THIRTY FIVE CIVILIANS AND MILITARY PERSONNEL caucusing and buzzing with the mission

dialogues.speaker: A HUGE PROJECTION SCREEN
dialogues.text: It's not a recon photo -- but the Ebola cellscape. A WAR MAP fills another screen.  It's of Washington D.C. and vicinity.  A series of expanding circles fan out from Reston, Virginia right over Washington D.C. GENERAL RUSSELL makes his point to a small group includin COL. TAKAFUJI of the Surgeon General's and an ASSISTANT from the Dept. of Interior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we have a respiratory threat -- and it gets loose -- up to ten million people could be exposed.

dialogues.speaker: TO C.J.
dialogues.text: Coffeed out and hot tempered, makes his point to GIRARD and some SUITS from Synergy along with CDC REPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This virus could jump and start burning through the human population right now.  Today.  We've got to get in there and depopulate the entire primate colony before that happens. Instant reaction.  All focus turns to C.J.'s group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about my company's investment? Not all the monkeys have symptoms. I'm not going to euthanize perfectly healthy specimens --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Army will handle the operation. C.J. is about to blow.  A familiar voice speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Army's done a great job -- CHUCK REESE separates the Army and Girard's contingent. Chuck hasn't changed much since that day 12 years ago wit Johnson in Africa.  Now in his late 30's, he's risen to the top of the heap at CDC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- up to now.  And everyone at CDC is really grateful, C.J., to your team for sounding the alarm.  We'll take over from here.  So if you'll give us virus samples and your data -- C.J. bristles at Reese's tone.  No love lost here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck, that sounds a little like "give the big boys the sharp objects before we hurt ourselves."  Synergy called in the Army and we will maintain our alert status.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.J. -- c'mon.  We don't need to start a war here. Battle lines drawn.  The room buzzes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in Africa with Karl Johnson during the Zaire event.  I worked in close contact with Ebola victims at Kinshasa for two months and was never infected. Reese grabs Peter's micrographs waving them around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was no data in Africa to support aerosol transmission -- We don't even know if it's the same strain. C.J. and the USAMRIID team argue in disarray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I recommend we low-key the press and media.  We can't afford to "cry wolf" to the American public -- A commotion at the back of the room disrupts everyone --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't afford not to --

dialogues.speaker: TO JOHNSON AND JAXX
dialogues.text: A major stir.  Raised eyebrows and confusion around. Johnson's name ripples through the room. Karl shakes C.J.'s hand as he dumps his bag on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late -- C.J. glares at Jaxx -- then nods a private "thank you." Jaxx lets out a huge sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karl -- glad you're here. Gen. Russell shakes his head waiting for the fireworks. Reese looks like a deer caught in the headlights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Johnson -- Karl, we were just wrapping up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm just beginning --

dialogues.speaker: FOLLOW JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Like Merlin and Clarence Darrow merged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monkeys, separated in cages with no social contact, are dying days and weeks apart from the first outbreak. That indicates a strong airborne transmission threat -- He illustrates the transmission pattern on a standup diagram of the monkey house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you, all of you, want to take the chance with innocent people? He fixes on Girard who can't hold his piercing gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to quarantine the Monkey Handlers and anyone who had unprotected contact -- NOW.  They could be exposed and incubating. You have to put a surveillance plan into action to watch their families and co-workers for symptoms -- Lots of reaction here.  Jaxx is mesmerized watching Karl ignite the room.  Girard has had it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this man in charge here? General Russell pulls C.J. aside --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better control him, C.J. C.J. just grins and nods, loving every minute of this. Reese jockeys for the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, we don't know if the virus can jump species from monkeys to people. Nobody's sick.  Right? Girard nods confirming this fact.  Reese scores points --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The monkeys with Ebola are going to die anyway.  We'll harvest the infected ones and save the rest. Girard and the Synergy contigent audibly approve.  The power has shifted visibly in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karl -- I think you're overreacting -- Wrong thing to say.   Karl drills Reese with his eyes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am...?  It only takes seven days to find out once you've got it. First come the headaches -- followed by a relentless fever.  Then the hemorrhaging begins.  Your skin goes pulpy and tears easily.  It speckles with petechiae -- erupts is a rash that turns your flesh to tapioca pudding.  Your bowels fill up completely with blood.  So do your eyeballs.  You vomit a thick black fluid -- After bloody diarrhea, you pass your intestines, what's left of them --

dialogues.speaker: JAXX SURVEYS THE ROOM
dialogues.text: Disgust, horror, fear.  One Man leaves the room nauseated

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man's testicles swell up the size of footballs.  And if you're not dead by then or comatose, you've become hostile -- acute psychosis -- dementia -- A Preacher's pause...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end, you're leaking blood and huge quantities of virus from the nose, mouth, anus, eyes, nipples -- rips in the skin... -- letting the images sink in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black plague killed four out of ten people.  When the white man and the red man exchanged diseases, seven out of ten died.  Ebola wipes the slate -- nine out of ten people in this room won't be here. He turns, making eye contact with everyone in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no choice -- but to cry wolf. ... Dead fucking silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter draws his own blood with a syringe.

dialogues.speaker: PETER IN HIS SPACESUIT
dialogues.text: He places his blood slide under the microscope and studie it on the monitor.  He sits back relieved.  He swivels in his stool to a wall calendar.

dialogues.speaker: THE CALENDAR
dialogues.text: He marks another day off in red.  Two down, five to go to the day he's marked "E-DAY"... Thanksgiving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody home? His voice vibrates through thin diaphragms set in the thick glass enabling communication into the suite. Peter walks to the glass happy to see his old mentor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just us flesheaters. Karl gets a good look at Peter close to the glass.  Guine Pigs fill the wall behind him.  His followers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard about your little flask sniffing episode.  How're you doing? Peter looks at the non-existent watch on his suit wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see, I was exposed two days ago.  Incubation takes about a week; therefore.  If I'm infected, I should be getting my first headaches in, oh, about five days.  If I spike a fever, seven days later -- the guys around here will be flipping coins to see who gets my vacation days -- Karl doesn't laugh.  Peter sobers under his stern eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the bug spreads by aerosol, you won't be the only one with a headache. Peter shys, almost sheepish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I've been sleeping here -- in the lab.  I don't want to expose my family... Karl is impressed by his protege's discipline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know you're not contagious unless you have symptoms, Pete. Don't woof me.  How's your blood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crossing his gloved fingers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Ebola antibodies yet.  The test tube-witch willing -- I can go home for Thanksgiving. He points to:  THE CALENDAR:  THANKSGIVING; five more days.  Peter smiles hopefully.  Karl sees the fear in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reese still doesn't believe the bug's airborne.  All that red tape must've choked off the air supply to his brain. Peter pushes his glasses back up on his nose through his plastic visor -- he motions Karl inside.

dialogues.speaker: MICROSCOPIC VIEW
dialogues.text: Crawling with the virus.  Armies of it.  A huge Ebola brick shaped like a shark fills the view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monkey snot -- Look at that big honker.  Definite airborne threat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karl peers at the monitor scope wearing surgical mask, visor, gloves and scrubs.  He sits back depressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate being right sometimes.  The monkey house is not the end.  It's the beginning. He muses -- eyes fixed on some other horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you fixed for Sister Genevieve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gold plated stuff.  Her immuno plasma is still the strongest therapy we've got against Ebola... At least in my guinea pigs. Peter reverently holds up a packet of plasma to the glass marked "Sister G."  Johnson savors it.  A long lost friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister "G"... she beats Ebola -- She beats it -- then dies of AIDS three years later she picked up in the same hospital... Hell, nobody said life was fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're down to less than four units.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not quite enough to fight an epidemic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Sister "G" was alive, I could clone her immune cells for my synthetic antibody trials.  We could crank out anti-ebola serum like a Chinese noodle factory.  We could immunize our troops -- dogs -- cats -- even politicians -- The two men share a moment of hopeful laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon.  Let's blow this fishtank. Beer and Pulitzer Pizza on me. Peter doesn't move.  He shakes his head reluctantly "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good virologist, Pete. Karl puts his gloved hand on the glass by Peter's.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: This funny little man in a blue spacesuit smiles shyly from the BL4 lab window like a big lonely blue fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry checks the leg cast on a BIRDDOG.  Blackhawk snooze at his feet.  Suddenly the Big Bouvier is up -- alert -- JAXX ENTERS from the house carrying a couple of beers still in her traveling clothes.  Ever up.  Tireless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room service. She hugs Gerry from behind rocking to and fro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you about an hour to stop that -- She plops beside him and pops the beers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the legendary Dr. Johnson? Still the "ladies man"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't kick him out of bed. She's pricking him.  Gerry punches her half-jealous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
